div.head: Introduction
div.p: This document compiles various concrete use cases implementing the suggested standOff element in order to refine the possible constraints that may bear upon it and its sub-elements. It is based on the experience gained in various projects since the initial workshop that launched the definition of this element as well as on some ongoing activities that are being pursued in several national projects in France and Germany (mong others), in international institutions (EPO) as well as in the content of several ISO projects (some of which have already been published as standards).

div.head: Aligning with the Open Annotation model
div.p: The Open Annotation data model articulates around three complementary components:

list.item: Target: that identifies one or several resources about which something is said
Body: that contains what is said about the resource
Annotation: that links one or several targets with 0-n bodies

div.head: Morphosyntactic annotation
div.p: ISO 24611 (MAF) contains a TEI based serialisation for morpho-syntactic annotations. The underlying model of ISO 24611 is based upon a two level model distinguishing between:

list.item: Tokens: elementary units segmented in the source textual content, and
Word forms: the abstract lexical units that may group together one or several tokens.

div.note: A token can also be associated to more than one word forms, e.g. in French: du, combining de and le.

div.head: Reference annotation
div.p: Reference annotation consists in identifying refering expression in text or discourse and qualify the relation between them (e.g. anaphorical links) or with existing or putative external entities (e.g. in the case of deixis).

div.head: Towards a content model for annotationBlock
div.p: In the case of an OA compliant model, the content model of annotationBlock shall be based upon three classes:

list.item: model.OAAnnotation: a mandatory clas reference for this annotation profile. The class should contain interp by default and one should be cautious in adding extra element to avoid ambiguous content models when the added element may also appear in the other classes.

div.p: In order to differentiate between the different encoding variants we have identified, the annotationBlock element must be associated to a notation attribute which can take one of the following values:

list.item: inSitu: non stand-off usage of annotation Block as documented in the Transcriptions of speech chapter.
OAModel: Open Annotation compliant model (Target, Body, Annotation)
